item.title: #en @ 1524191092752609280
item.description:
Police have shot and killed 368 people so far in 2022 (an average of 2.9 per day). Houston, TX leads the nation with 6 fatal police shootings this year.
@houstonpolice #wapo #dataanalysis #twitterbot #policeshooting #cops #bot #opendata #stats #publicrecords #reform

item.title: #en @ 1524116412729643010
item.description: 1/3 Re the open data discussions, it is interesting to see how much people differentiate between data, tools for analyzing data, and tools for collecting data. Datasets are given a special status per the intellectual labor that goes into developing them. But what about tools?

item.title: #en @ 1524093869595394049
item.description:
My take on the open data debate:
The original author(s) should always be contacted and invited to collaborate.
It isnâ€™t about ownership; itâ€™s that the person or team that spearheaded the data collection has, in most cases, already made a substantive intellectual contribution.

item.title: #en @ 1524089135971110913
item.description:
Are there any open data sets, from surveys of researchersâ€™ motivations to share data? #OpenScience
(I know this question sounds tongue in cheek but I am really asking.)

item.title: #en @ 1524087721500626945
item.description: $NWBO The presentation didnâ€™t start until 11:10 est but the stock started dumping from the open. Data was good so couldnâ€™t have been a leak. Likely some manipulation going on. Not mad since I picked up more shares. @FlemmingBruce Thank you for you DD. Itâ€™s not over

item.title: #en @ 1524085611425976320
item.description:
Super late to this convo today, but I wanted to give some thoughts on open data. No judgement here, just my personal views.
First, I don't think I own my data and I don't think you own your data. If we're talking about psychology or psychiatry, the public own the data. 1/13

item.title: #en @ 1524066257846296576
item.description:
@yannaweisberg @ashleylwatts @KMKing_Psych @LisaStarrPhD i'll add another take: open data allows researchers who might not have the resource to collect such data benefit from those who can
if we want to provide equity, then providing open data is a great way to break down systemic issues related to collecting it

item.title: #en @ 1524020779544977410
item.description:
@AleksaKaurin As an author, I would like it if I was contacted before someone published with some of my open data, but I wouldnâ€™t feel wronged if they didnâ€™t, granted they appropriately cited the parent work.
2/2

item.title: #en @ 1524020629711855619
item.description:
@AleksaKaurin As a data downloader, my assumption is if theyâ€™re open, Iâ€™m free to do what I want with a data set. E.g., Iâ€™ve highlighted open data sets in some of my blog posts without asking the prior research team beforehand.
1/2

item.title: #en @ 1523980152937631744
item.description:
@AleksaKaurin Short answer: yes ok to publish.
Seen situations where open data were reused & some original authors (medicine) were upset they werenâ€™t asked for permission. I donâ€™t think this is an understanding we have in psychology with open data. If data is open they can be used imo.

item.title: #en @ 1523968597550374914
item.description:

https://t.co/HUaw10SGUg #Coal2Clean #OpenData https://t.co/LYdnKbMDYQ

item.title: #en @ 1523908406868058112
item.description:
I think it's fair to say we (the reserach field) solve a couple of problems:
1. open research output 2. interoperability
FAIR and Open data is reality and beyond the hype. It's just adoption that is lacking.
Deep Learning already knows this. They're at full speed. 1/
